user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_uio_dev_irq_ack:
```c
static void metal_uio_dev_irq_ack(struct linux_bus *lbus,
				 struct linux_device *ldev,
				 int irq)
{
	(void)lbus;
	(void)irq;
	int irq_info = 1;
	unsigned int val;
	int ret;

	ret = read(ldev->fd, (void *)&val, sizeof(val));
	if (ret < 0) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "%s, read uio irq fd %d failed: %d.\n",
						__func__, ldev->fd, ret);
		return;
	}
	ret = write(ldev->fd, &irq_info, sizeof(irq_info));
	if (ret < 0) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "%s, write uio irq fd %d failed: %d.\n",
						__func__, ldev->fd, errno);
	}
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function metal_uio_dev_irq_ack:
struct linux_bus {
	struct metal_bus	bus;
	const char		*bus_name;
	struct linux_driver	drivers[MAX_DRIVERS];
	struct sysfs_bus	*sbus;
}
...
struct linux_device {
	struct metal_device		device;
	char				dev_name[PATH_MAX];
	char				dev_path[PATH_MAX];
	char				cls_path[PATH_MAX];
	metal_phys_addr_t		region_phys[METAL_MAX_DEVICE_REGIONS];
	struct linux_driver		*ldrv;
	struct sysfs_device		*sdev;
	struct sysfs_attribute		*override;
	int				fd;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I examined the function for use of language/compiler extensions (examples: GCC/Clang/MSVC extensions such as __attribute__, statement expressions ({ ... }), typeof, inline assembler, nested functions, GCC builtins, nonstandard keywords, or compiler-specific predefined identifiers). I found none of those constructs in the supplied code. Specific notes:

- __func__ is used; this is a standard identifier in C99 and later (not a compiler-specific extension).
- (void)lbus; and (void)irq; are standard idiom to suppress unused-parameter warnings (not an extension).
- Calls to read(), write() and usage of errno are POSIX library/system calls, not language extensions.
- The cast (void *)&val is a plain pointer cast (standard C).
- Variable declarations and initializations used are standard C (C99/C11); they are not compiler-specific extensions.
- No __attribute__, __builtin_*, typeof, asm, statement-expressions, or other known compiler-specific constructs were present.

If you expect a specific compiler that documents any of these constructs as an extension (for example an older compiler that lacks C99 support and treats __func__ or mixed declarations as extensions), please provide that compiler and its documentation; I can re-evaluate and flag the relevant fragments accordingly.
